name: Blueberries, raw
description: Raw blueberries (Vaccinium spp.), edible fruit portions

mental_health_impacts.mechanism: Anthocyanins and other flavonoids reduce neuroinflammation and oxidative stress in the brain, while improving blood flow to cognitive regions
mental_health_impacts.research_context: Multiple human RCTs show improved memory and executive function, particularly in older adults

research_support.citation: Krikorian R, et al. Blueberry supplementation improves memory in older adults. J Agric Food Chem. 2010;58(7):3996-4000.
Miller MG, et al. Dietary blueberry improves cognition among older adults in a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Eur J Nutr. 2018;57(3):1169-1180.

mental_health_impacts.mechanism: Polyphenols and vitamin C reduce oxidative stress and inflammation associated with depressive symptoms; flavonoids modulate neurotransmitter systems
mental_health_impacts.research_context: Observational studies show associations between berry consumption and reduced depression risk; limited intervention studies

research_support.citation: Chang SC, et al. High anthocyanin intake is associated with a reduced risk of depression in middle-aged and older women. J Nutr. 2022;152(2):505-514.

mental_health_impacts.mechanism: Antioxidants in blueberries help reduce cortisol production and mitigate physiological stress responses
mental_health_impacts.research_context: Limited human studies, some evidence from animal models

research_support.citation: Williams CM, et al. Blueberry-induced changes in spatial working memory correlate with changes in hippocampal CREB phosphorylation and brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) levels. Free Radic Biol Med. 2008;45(3):295-305.
